Hi Milt!  Hope all is well with you and your family.  I have to 
wonder if sometimes what we think is 'fire scale' may actually be oil 
rust which is lifting the oxidized outer layer of the metal?  Also I 
have to wonder if the effect might be explainable to analogize to 
the 'glazing' process of dental porcalain (I just had to get 
dentistry into this to bug you) which is when you subject the object 
to very high heat for short duration which only melts the surface as 
opposed to lower heat of longer duration (as in a fire) which more 
evenly heats the object.  Something for the metalurgists to ponder.---
 In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "bungotakadasword" 
<MuramasaIII@a...> wrote:
>  "  yakite shitate = a surface finish resembling the glaze on 
pottery. 
> Produced by
> putting the finished plate back into the furnace and allowing the 
> surface to
> melt slightly. "
> 
> 
> this brings to mind about the effect of " fire damage " we 
sometimes 
> see in tsuba................
> How come some tsuba develop " fire scales " and some develop  " a 
> surface finish resembling the glaze on pottery "  ?
> I used to have a tsuba with gold nunome AND " fire scales "......if 
> that tsuba was under fire high enough to develop fire scales, then 
how 
> come the gold nunome did not melt ?
> Assuming fire scales develop under " low heat ", then can we repair 
the 
> fire damage  by subjecting the tsuba to high heat , at least we'll 
get 
> a Hoan look ?
> 
> milt
